# 297\n
{Edinburgh, Royal College of Physicians, MS of Cursor Mundi, hand A, fols. 1r-15v}\n
C14a\n
486 447 N\n
{=ERY=}\n
{=Sample represents all the English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - small compressed Textura=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The extracts from Cursor Mundi in this MS are imperfect and wrongly\n
ordered. Hand C provides the earlier portions, Cursor Mundi lines\n
18989-22417 (with gaps). Hand A provides lines 22418-24359, 24530-730,\n
24733-968. Between Hand A\'s and Hand C\'s contributions Hand B provides\n
some of the Northern Homily Collection. Hand A\'s contribution begins\n
in Morris\'s edition vol. 5 (EETS OS 68, 1878), Appendix 1, p. 1616 and\n
continues at vol. 5 p. 1367. The scribe\'s thorn is open-topped but quite\n
different in shape from <y>, which is also used quite extensively for\n
both [i] and [j], unlike Scribe C\'s habit. Punctuation is virtually\n
absent. Punctus on either side of capital <I> are taken to be part of\n
the figura and are ignored. Forms of majuscule and minuscule thorn,\n
<w> and <v> are identical in this hand. The majuscule forms of all\n
other letters are regularly used at the start of each verse line.\n
I have followed Morris in indicating capitals in this position for\n
thorn <w> and <v> also. In his edition, Morris expands the usual\n
abbreviation for <er> either as <ir> or <er> according to the word. Here\n
I always expand, as with our normal practice, as <er>. In hand C, the\n
same abbreviation (a hook above the preceding letter) is used after A as\n
an abbreviation for "and". Hand A also uses this hook abbreviation on A\n
for "and" though his <er> abbreviation is different - an upright zigzag\n
above the preceding letter. For "and" I follow what I did in language 2\n
of the Cotton Owl and the Nightingale and with Hand C of this MS, and\n
transcribe A~=}\n
{~f1ra~}\n

{="move, activate". I take this to be the verb "stir" not "steer"\n
because of the semantic context. The word does appear with medial <e> in\n

alternative is to take it as "steer" with the otherwise unattested\n
meaning "engage in"? see MED s.v. ste:ren v. 4. There is considerable\n
semantic and formal overlap between these two words=}\n

{=The other versions have either "he" or "it" rather than "I" here. The\n
point is that we are all in our redeemed state "God\'s temple" and that\n
is why we have to be glorified and clothed in brightness. The syntax\n
switches from all redeemed souls ("them") to the temple and then to "I"\n
as one individual example of the temple of the body - the dwelling place\n
of Christ=}\n

{=MS RAIyE with I subpuncted=}\n
{=I take this to mean "concerning many a piece of advice". MED construes\n
RAyE as connected to OIr raithe and Scots raith "quarter of the year" on\n
the basis of the syntax of the Cotton version. This does not fit the\n
syntax of the other versions however and in any case makes not such good\n
sense in context=}\n

$rest/n{rh}_REST\n
{=This is hard to parse as there is probably some textual corruption. I\n
take REST as a noun because the syntax does not seem to allow it to\n
be a past participle. HORDES is most likely a corruption of "hoard" and "is"\n
because in this scribe\'s system present plurals are usually endingless, and\n
always so in immediate proximity to a personal pronoun. Other versions have\n
"But that [which] in heart\'s hoard [or root] is rested [i.e. remains]"=}\n
{\\}\n

{="unstrong, infirm" - an otherwise unattested negative form of ste:re "strong, firm"=}\n
$in{c}/pr_IN\n
{=Morris (1878) prints *VNSTERIN and takes the word to be a form of\n
"unstern". Although the limb of R touches the I of IN there is a larger than\n
usual gap between the minim strokes and reading as two words is plausible. This\n
scribe in any case does run words together frequently. This reading helps both\n
sense and syntax=}\n

\n
# 298\n
{Edinburgh, Royal College of Physicians, MS of Cursor Mundi, hand B, fols. 16r-36v: Extracts from the Northern Homily Collection}\n
C14a\n
455 476 N\n
{=NRY=}\n
{=Sample represents all the English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - small neat Textura=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The extracts from the Northern Homily Collection are sandwiched\n
between two imperfect and wrongly ordered sections of Cursor Mundi\n
in Hands A and C. The only edition is the 1862 one by John Small who\n
expands abbreviations silently and normalises much of the spelling.\n
The changes are so extensive I have made no attempt to note their\n
occurrences. The scribe\'s thorn is open-topped but different in\n
shape from <y>, which is also used beside <i> for both [i] and [j], unlike\n
Scribe C\'s habit. Punctuation is virtually absent except at the\n
beginning where the space left for the enlarged capital throws\n
the lineation out for four lines and punctus are therefore\n
employed to indicate verse line ends. Punctus on either side\n
of capital <I> are taken to be part of the figura and are\n
ignored. Forms of majuscule and minuscule thorn, <w> and <v> are\n
identical in this hand. The majuscule forms of all other letters\n
are regularly used at the start of each verse line. I have followed\n
Small in indicating capitals in this position for thorn <w> and <v>\n
also. Abbreviations are usually standard and expanded in the normal way.\n
As with Hand C, the same abbreviation as for <er> (a hook over the preceding\n
letter is also sometimes used on stem-final double <l> where <er> would\n
not be a suitable expansion. Here I have transcribed the abbreviation as\n
~, e.g. TELL~ for "tells". Another abbreviation for <er> is a broken\n
vertical line above where the letters are missing. This is also used\n
for <re> and is expanded in these cases according to context. Spaces\n
have been left for two-line initial capitals not carried out. Visible\n
guide letters supply the lack as noted. Sectional paraphs may also\n
have been left for the rubricator to fill in. Hairline double hyphens,\n
as noted, serve as paraphs=}\n
{~f16ra~}\n
$father/n-voc_>*F>*ADER\n
{=Space has been left for a 3-line illuminated capital which has not\n
been carried out. *F is in the form of a guide letter (doubled\n
minuscule F) in the left side of the empty box=}\n
$&/cj_AND\n
$son/n-voc_SUN\n
$&/cj_AnD\n
$holy/aj-voc_HAL+I+ $-ig/xs-aj-voc_+I+\n
$ghost/n-voc{rh}_+GAST\n
{\\}\n
$/RTA_*yAT\n
$1fold/qc-aj_AN+FALD $-fold/xs-aj_+FALD\n
$god/n_GOD\n
$be/vps13_ES\n
$ay/av_AY\n
{\\}\n

{\\\\}\n
{=A fragmentary unnumbered folio is misbound in here, not affecting the\n
running text. Just the bottom left corner survives. The recto has the\n
beginning of the three last lines visible: *A, *W and *yA. The verso has no\n
writing because it corresponds only to the outer margin=}\n
{~f17ra~}\n
{(*EXPLICIT ISTUD PreCEDEnS ARGUMenTUm(}\n
{.}\n
{(*INCIPIT EUaNGELiuM EIusDEM DomiNICE(}\n
{\\}\n
{=From here until the end of the Latin introduction, the text is indented.\n
The ruling allows for a separate column for the litterae notabiliores at the\n
start of each line and this column is ignored until the English text restarts=}\n
{(*SECUNDUM *MARCUM(}\n
{.}\n
{\\}\n
{([]*NICIUM EWANGeLIJ IHesU XPistI FILIJ \\ DEI . SICUT SCr^IPTUm EST In YSAYA ProPHETA .\n
\\ *ECCE MITTO ANGeLuM MEUm ANTe \\ FACIEm TUAm QUI PrePARABIT UIAM \\ TUAM ANTE TE . VOX\n
CLAMANTI^S \\ INDESERTO ParATE UIAM DomiNI . \\ RECTAS SEMITAS FACITE EIUS . *FUIT *IOHanES\n
IN DESERTO . & CETerA .(}\n

{.}\n
{(AMen(}\n
{.}\n
{\\\\}\n
{(\'*DOminicA II^A . *ADUENTus *DomiNI . SeCunDuM *LUCAM.\'(}\n
{\\}\n
{=space left for two-line capital, not carried out. D supplied from guide\n
letter in the left side of the empty box=}\n
{(>D>*IXIT IHesus DISCIPuLIS SUIS . *ERUNT \\ SIGNA IN SOLE & LUNA & [ST]ELLis(}\n
{=MS reading looks like FELLis but this makes no sense and "stars" is\n
required. The crossbar of the F is presumably the T whose stem has\n
merged with that of E=}\n
{(& IN \\ TerRIS PreSSURA GENTIUm Pre conFUSIONE SINI\\Tus MARIS & FLUCTUUm\n
. ARESCENTIBus \\ HOminIBus Pre TIMORE & EXPECTATiOnE QUE \\ SupeRUENIEnT\n
UNIUerSO ORBI . & Cetera .(}\n
{\\}\n
{(*INCIPIT EXPLANATIO EIUSDEM EU^AN\\GELIJ AD [LU]CAM.(}\n
{=The scribe appears to have written MarCAM in error and has changed the\n
first minim of M to L and then left the rest allowing the abbreviation to\n

$pre:onan/vps13_Pr^INN+ES $/vps13[N]_+ES\n
{="pierces?, injures?". Small (1862) prints PINNES but the superscript I\n
as abbreviation for RI is clear. See MED pre:nen v., especially in relation\n
to MED priken v. sense 1 (c). The senses of priken and pre:nen cover both\n
"pierce" and "pin together" in both literal and figurative senses. Cf. also\n
MED prinnen v. which I believe should be listed rather under pre:nen with\n
the sense "secure"=}\n

{\\\\}\n
{(\'*UNDE UerSUS DE EIUSDEM SIGNIS\'(}\n
{=There now follow the fifteen signs before Doomsday in Latin\n
in rhyming couplets with apparently one rhyming line missing - 33\n
lines altogether - taking up the rest of this column of text and\n
half of the next=}\n
{\\}\n
{~f19vb~}\n
{=English text begins again half way down this column=}\n
{(*ISTI UERSus OMITTAnTUR A LECTORE Qu^ANDO LEGIT \\ *ANGLICUm CORAM LAYCIS(}\n
{.}\n
{\\}\n
{=ins, in left hand margin, a double hyphen=}\n
$then/av_*yAN\n
$shall/vps13_SAL\n
$christ/n_Cr^IST\n

{=Small (1862) prints TAKING here (as in the next line) perhaps assuming\n
the word to be a form of "token". But the spelling here suggests\n
that it is more likely to be a verbal noun from the verb "take"\n
with a sense similar to "token", namely, "indication, evidence".\n
See MED s.v. ta:ken v. sense 32 (a) and cf. MED s.v. ta:king(e ger.\n
sense 18 (d) and the quotation there cited=}\n

$to/pr_TO\n
$arraign/vn<prF_REIN+IGE $/vn<prF_+IGE\n
{=Small (1862) reads ROUNGE, see MED roungen v. which means "chew on, gnaw,\n
consume". MED cites this reading under sense 1 (c) and suggests "be\n
tormented" which stretches the sense a great deal. I am confident\n
that Small\'s reading is not right not least because an infinitive is\n
not what the syntax demands here. The second letter is almost\n
certainly a badly formed E with an enlarged bow making it seem\n
O-like. This scribe quite frequently forms E in this way. I believe\n
the correct reading to be REINIGE. A verbal noun makes more sense\n
syntactically and this scribe seems always to have -IGE ending\n
for verbal nouns if the verb\'s stem ends in N. He rarely defines\n
I with a hairline stroke outwith minim contexts and does not always\n
do so even in minim contexts so lack of hairlines is no bar to this\n
reading. Semantically it is far superior; see MED reinen v. (3) and\n
cf. arreinen v. both used in the context of the Day of Judgment and\n
both meaning "arraign, try". The verbal noun is not cited but would\n
mean "trial, judgment". This reading if accepted would be an\n
ante-dating of the verb in English=}\n

$in{p}/pr_>I>*N\n
{=MS *N as littera notabilior standing alone. I is added in left hand\n
margin presumably as a correction. Guide letters are not normal for the\n
simple rubricated capitals. This phenomenon happens more than once and\n
may have come about because the litterae notabiliores were done after the\n
main text and perhaps the exemplar text had *I standing alone for "in"\n
whereas this scribe never does so. Nevertheless it is an odd choice for\n
the rubricator to put *N to stand for the word=}\n

{=Three folios are lost from the MS here. Small\'s  (1862) edition\n
supplies the missing text from two different sources. The\n
Edinburgh text continues in the middle of the sermon for the\n
eighth Sunday after the Nativity. The text resumes in the middle\n
of an exemplary tale. It concerns an archbishop who, out of lust,\n
blackmails a young nun to have sex with him. The following text\n
tells how through penance he then regains grace=}\n

$for/cj_*FOR\n
$as/pr_ALS\n
{=Here, and elsewhere as marked, ALS seems to have the function of a\n
preposition with the temporal sense "on". It appears to be a northern\n
usage though I can find no mention of it in OED or MED. It is listed in\n
DOST s.v. As, adv. and conj. sense 4 and is taken to be a reduced form\n
of "as of, as to" meaning "in regards, in respect or consideration of".\n
See the quotations under (3): Darius...echapyd as that day; Wynt IV.\n
660. As this tid.. with him he wald nocht bide; Wall. I. 313. KW (pers.\n
comm.) reports many instances of this prepositional use of "as" in the\n
Older Scots documents.  A possible mechanism for this usage to have\n
arisen might be as follows: (1) "as" used in combination with preposition,\n
perhaps most commonly in legal phraseology, e.g. "as on this day",\n
"as at this time"; (2) possible simplifications of this usage could\n
involve: either omitting "as", reverting to the more common, simple\n
prepositional phrase, "on this day", "at this time"; or omitting the\n
original preposition and letting the "as" substitute for it. The latter\n
seems to be what has happened here. Because the phrase seems formally\n
to require a preposition I have tagged "as" accordingly=}\n
$/Dis<pr_yIS\n

$today/av_DO-DAI $to-/xp-av_DO-\n
{=It might be argued that the first D could just possibly be read\n
as a very badly formed T. But the \'crossbar\' is angled and looks\n
much more like the oblique ascender of D although, unlike either T\n
or usual D in this hand, its end is somewhat splayed (cf, however,\n
the second D in DID f29ra line 2, which is very like this).\n
Crucially, the way the letter has been formed with biting of the\n
lobe of the D with the following O makes it most likely to have\n
been intended (whether mistakenly or not) as a D=}\n

$read/vps21{rh}_RED+E $/vps21{rh}_+E\n
{\\}\n
!_*ROB\n
{=The C version of this text has "but". Here the *R and the B are quite\n
clear. The vowel is probably O but could just possibly be read as E.\n
Small\'s (1862) suggestion that it is for ROV "cloth" from OE "reov"\n
(as he puts it) is highly unlikely. OE re:af is normally "garment,\n
vestment" and would not be found in a candle. I do not know what\n
the word can be, but the context requires that it mean the material\n
from which a candlewick is made. MED s.v. ribbe n. 2 cites spellings\n
in reb-, rob- and rub- as well as rib- but there is no evidence that\n
"ribwort" or "plantain" (the meanings given) have fibres suitable for\n
candlewicks, unless "ribbe" could also be used for flax or tow. Other\n
possibilities are that *ROB is written for "rope" (but in this\n
language we would expect RAP(E)) or that it is an error for "reed"\n
which also seems far-fetched=}\n
$wick/n_WEC\n
$/RTI_yAT\n

{=Text ends imperfectly. Hand C begins on the next folio with part of the Cursor Mundi=}\n

\n'
b'
\n
# 296\n
{Edinburgh, Royal College of Physicians, MS of Cursor Mundi, hand C, fols. 37r-50v}\n
C14a\n
460 452 N\n
{=York=}\n
{=Sample represents all the English in this hand. The extracts from\n
Cursor Mundi in this MS are imperfect and wrongly ordered. Hand C\n
provides the earlier portions, Cursor Mundi lines 18989-22417 (with\n
gaps). Hand A provides some later portions while between the two\n
contributions Hand B provides some of the Northern Homily Collection.\n
This hand\'s contribution begins in Morris\'s edition vol. 5 (1878), Appendix\n
1, p. 1587=}\n
{=Script - a small neat Textura=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Thorn is thorn-shaped not <y>-shaped. The scribe only seems to\n
use the littera \'y\' in names eg YSAAC, but it is clear from this\n
that he does distinguish their shapes. Otherwise, the avoidance\n
of \'y\' is very deliberate, for vocalic [i] he always uses <i> and\n
for [j] he uses <g>. Punctuation is virtually absent except on fol.\n
38r where the scribe has a punctus at every line end. He does not\n
however keep this up beyond the recto of the folio. On this folio also\n
he ornaments the ascenders of the letters on the top line and the\n
descenders of the letters on the bottom line. Again this seems to be a\n
temporary flight of fancy. Occasionally, if the last word of a line\n
will not fit the column width and has to be taken to the end of the\n
line below or above, a punctus is used to divide it from the text\n
belonging to the other line. Where this happens the punctus is\n
included and its use explained. Punctus on either side of capital <I>\n
are taken to be part of the figura and are ignored. In his edition\n
Morris expands the usual abbreviation for <er> either as <ir> or <er>\n
according to the word. Here I always expand, as with our normal\n
practice, as <er>. The same abbreviation (a hook above the preceding\n
letter) is used after A as an abbreviation for "and". Here I follow\n
what I did in language 2 of the Cotton Owl and the Nightingale and\n
transcribe A~. A similar hook is sometimes used stem finally, and is\n
realised in the same way, e.g. ELL~ rather than ELLes or ELLis. The\n
scribe usually has the same yogh-shaped symbol for yogh and <z> which\n
I realise always as yogh i.e. lower case <z>. Where it is <z>-shaped\n
it is realised as Z=}\n
{~f37r~}\n
$in{p}/pr_*IN\n
$heaven/n<pr_HEUIN\n
$on{p}/pr_ON\n
$high/ajn<pr_HEIE\n
$then/av_yAN\n
$shall/vps11_SALE\n
$/P11N_*I\n
$show/viK2{rh}_SCAW+E $/viK2{rh}_+E\n
{=i.e. "show wonders"=}\n
{\\}\n
$&/cj_*AND\n
$sign/nplOd_SIGN+IS $/plnOd_+IS\n
$down/av_DUNE\n
$on{p}/pr_ON\n

{)*yE *IUEN FOLC AMANG yOU GA)}\n
{=This line in a different hand apparently written in a space left by\n
the main scribe as there is no sign of it being on an erasure. The\n
other versions of the text have these two lines in reverse order, so\n
the simplest explanation is that the exemplar used by the main scribe\n
lacked the added line completely. The main scribe only noticed the\n
problem when he discoverd there was no rhyme for SLA and so left the\n
line empty to be supplied later in the wrong order by the second scribe=}\n

{=according to Morris (1878) four leaves are lost here corresponding to lines\n
20150-20800. But there is a fragmentary leave bound in between fols. 48\n
and 49 which he later makes no reference to and which in fact has\n
portions of lines 20633-653 (on the recto) and 20757-782 (on the verso).\n
I call this fragment fol. 48* and include it here because its text\n
belongs between the last line above (20149) and the next line following\n
(20801)=}\n

{~f46ra~}\n
{=Here for the next 246 lines, the Edinburgh text is used by Morris to\n
fill a gap in his edition of the Trinity version running parallel to\n
Cotton, Fairfax and Gottingen. See vol iv (EETS OS 66 (1877) pp. 1237-51).\n
Morris\'s editorial procedures are therefore different for this stretch,\n
the abbrevations usually being expanded silently. I continue to notice\n
substantive errors or misprints in Morris\'s text but I do not note\n
in this 246-line stretch those occasions where he fails to italicise\n
abbrevations=}\n

$virtue/n<pr{rh}_UerTU\n
{=This is a curious lapse into French presumably triggered by the\n
fact that "sign" and "virtue" are both French loans. It may even\n
have been a failure of the original author to translate from a\n
French source at this point, suggesting if so that the Edinburgh\n
MS may be very close to such an original version. The other versions\n
all have Englished versions of the phrase "sign of great virtue"=}\n

{=The meaning of this is uncertain. The other versions all vary here\n
suggesting some textual uncertainty or corruption. This may be an\n
attempt at the name of an otherwise unknown romance hero, or possibly a\n
form of song accompanied by rote (see MED). My own very tentative\n
hypothesis, given the unusually alliterative nature of this line and the\n
poem\'s northern origins, is that it may be in imitation of alliterative\n
verse cf. Chaucer\'s: I kan nat geste rom ram ruf by lettre. But this is\n
impossible to be sure about=}\n

$&/cj_A~\n
!_BA~\n
{=Morris (1878) transcribes this BAer. But given that the abbreviation is the\n
same one used in different contexts for <er>, <nd> (in "and"), <is> or\n
<es> in verbal endings etc. It is not certain what it represents here.\n
The word is not present in the other versions and if if is read BAer it\n
could conceivably be for the adjective "bare" or the noun "boar". But\n
arguably it could indicate BArn. I have not attempted to tag the word\n
unless and until a similar use of the abbreviation in another context\n
may give a clue. The word in in any case metrically redundant and is not\n
needed by the sense=}\n
$bold/aj<pr{rh}_BALD\n

{=Morris (1878) prints THOLINGE. The first letter could be either T or C but\n
looks more like the scribe\'s usual C. "The Lord\'s suffering" does not\n
seem to make much sense here. Other versions vary and there may be\n
some textual corruption here, but two have "choseling" "elected" and\n
I assume CHOLINGE is a form of this with S missing=}\n

{=i.e. Simon Magus=}\n
$have/vi_HAU+E $/vi_+E\n
$slay/vSpp{rh}_SLA+N $/vSpp[V]{rh}_+N\n
{=This is a very elliptical reference to the story of Simon Magus  who\n
asked Nero to behead him so that he could rise again on the third day as\n
an act of magic. Simon substituted a sheep which Nero killed thinking it\n
was Simon, but (Morris (1892) part VI, p. lii, notes): \'when the head was\n
brought to light it proved to be a sheep\'s head\'=}\n

$/P13NM_HE\n
$stecan{*}/vi{rh}_STECK+E $/vi{rh}_+E\n
{"decide?"}\n
{=The meaning of this passage is unclear to me though the general gist\n
is obvious. A literal translation is "to be found so shall he stick"\n
which does not seem to make much sense given the next clause. Gottingen\n
has the same wording. Fairfax and Trinity paraphrase to make sense but\n
each choose a different way out, suggesting scribal editing. Cotton has\n
STERCK perhaps written for STRECK "move quickly" which fits better with\n
jumping over hills. See Morris (1892) vol VI, notes who thinks "streak"\n
is probably the correct reading and who provides a very loose paraphrase\n
for this passage=}\n

{=Sample tagged: fols. 35v-36v; 72v-73r. Note - there are other brief verses\n
in English in this manuscript, which may or may not be in the same hand=}\n

{=This version unusual in having the Candet verses not only in Latin\n
first but also in French before the English appears=}\n

VNDA. *HEC SUnT UerBA SanCtI AUGUSTINI.(}\n
